subject: RE: [junit] Re: New to JUnit
msgSnippet: If you know what node is changing (which you should) and what the new value is supposed to be (which you should), you can just very simply do the calculation,
messageBody:
If you know what node is changing (which you should) and what the new value
is supposed to be (which you should), you can just very simply do the
calculation, create a MockNode in your test that contains this new value and
assert that the two are equal. This presumes that the calculate method is
already tested and working properly.

But that begs the question, if the only functionality of the state change
method is to forward a call to some other objects calculation method, is it
necessary to test the method in the TreeHolder class?

-Jason
> -----Original Message-----
> From: reply_das@... [mailto:reply_das@...]
> Sent: Monday, July 30, 2001 8:40 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: New to JUnit
>
>
> --- In junit@y..., Johannes Link <john.link@g...> wrote:
> > With which part of your TreeHolder functionality have
> you testing
> > problems? The build up or the state changes?
> > Can you share (at least part of) your code base, so
> that we can more
> > easily grasp the exact semantics?
> >
> > Johannes
> >
>
> Hi Johannes,
> Thanks for your reply. My TreeHolder class is something like this:
>
> // Note: MyNode implements MutableTreeNode interface
> // and holds a UserDefinedObject
>
> public class TreeHolder {
>
> MyNode rootNode; //the root node for the whole tree
>
> public TreeHolder(Collection items) {
> //constructor logic to build MyNodes out of the input
> //items and set rootNode as the root of the generated
> //tree of MyNodes.
>
> rootNode = ... //build a MyNode Tree From "items"
> }
>
> public void calculateSomething(int contextValue) {
>
> //This changes the state of some MyNodes in the tree
> rootNode.calculateSomething(contextValue);
> }
>
> //.... several such calculate methods
>
> public void summarizeAll() {
>
> //This again changes the state in some other way.
> rootNode.summarizeAll();
> }
>
> public MyPackagedObject getAsNewPacakgedObject() {
>
> //This packages the MyNode tree into a flattened
> //object and returns it.
>
> return rootNode.newPackagedObject();
> }
> }
>
> I have written TestCases for the MyNode object already. Every
> calculate method on TreeHolder changes the state of the
> rootNode (or
> one/many subnodes.) So, how do I go about testing if the state
> changes are correct? Or rather, should I even be writing
> them (since
> TestMyNode may already covers those cases?)
>
> Thanks in advance for your help.
> --Das
